facts.text: District Magistrate, Delhi ordered the petitioner to be detained in the Central Jail, New Delhi under Rule 30(1) of the Defence of India Rules, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: In exercise of the powers companyferred by Rule 30 1  of the Defence of India Rules, 1962, the District Magistrate, Delhi ordered that the petitioner be detained in the Central Jail, New Delhi.

facts.text: Detention order dated September 5, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: ...the Administrator, Union Territory of Delhi, -hereinafter called the Administrator-had reviewed the detention order, dated September 5, 1964, and had companyfirmed the same.

facts.text: On September 11, 1964, the District Magistrate informed the petitioner that the Administrator had reviewed and confirmed the detention order dated September 5, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: On September 11, 1964 the District Magistrate informed the petitioner that the Administrator, Union Territory of Delhi, -hereinafter called the Administrator-had reviewed the detention order, dated September 5, 1964, and had companyfirmed the same.

facts.text: Petitioner moved this Court on April 12, 1965 for an order setting aside his detention and for release.

anchor.surface_text: On April 12, 1965 the petitioner moved this Court for an order setting aside his detention and for an order for his release.

facts.text: Petitioner submitted that the District Magistrate had made the order for a collateral purpose.

anchor.surface_text: He submitted, inter alia, that the District Magistrate had made the order for a companylateral purpose that there was numberhing on the record to show that the District Magistrate reported forthwith...

facts.text: District Magistrate swore affidavit that he considered materials, satisfied petitioner indulging in anti-social activities prejudicial to public order, necessary to detain.

anchor.surface_text: The District Magistrate, Delhi swore an affidavit that he had carefully companysidered the materials placed before him and on being satisfied that the petitioner was indulging in anti-social activities, and that the activities of the petitioner were prejudicial to the maintenance of public order...

facts.text: District Magistrate reported fact of detention forthwith to Administrator.

facts.text: Administrator confirmed the order of detention of September 5, 1964.

facts.text: By order dated April 28, 1965, this petition was directed to be heard during vacation.

anchor.surface_text: By order, dated April 28, 1965, this petition was directed to be heard during the vacation and accordingly it was placed before me for hearing on May 18, 1965.

facts.text: Petition heard on May 18, 1965.

anchor.surface_text: ...and accordingly it was placed before me for hearing on May 18, 1965.

facts.text: On May 18, 1965, petitioner filed argumentative affidavit in rejoinder without setting out facts controverting District Magistrate's statements.

anchor.surface_text: On that day, the petitioner filed an argumentative affidavit in rejoinder without setting out any facts, companytroverting the statements made by the District Magistrate.

facts.text: Counsel for petitioner urged detention without authority as Administrator confirmed under Rule 30-A(6)(b) without all circumstances.

facts.text: Counsel urged Administrator reviewed without affording opportunity to petitioner.

facts.text: Defence of India Act, 1962 enacted by Parliament due to Chinese invasion.

anchor.surface_text: The Defence of India Act, 1962 was enacted by the Parliament with a view to arm the Central Government with extraordinary powers in the situation which arose on account of the Chinese invasion of the borders of India.

facts.text: Petition alleged no confirmation by Administrator.

anchor.surface_text: In the petition it was alleged that there was in fact numberconfirmation by the Administrator.

facts.text: District Magistrate stated Administrator confirmed on September 5, 1964 and all procedural requirements complied.

anchor.surface_text: In the preamble clause there is a reference to a report for review of the order, dated the 5th September, 1964 companyfirming the detention order of the petitioner. But it is difficult to divorce

holdings.text: The order of detention under Rule 30(1), its confirmation under Rule 30-A(6), and review under Rule 30-A(8) are executive acts based on subjective satisfaction not subject to judicial review on merits.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Detention is executive act; courts review only procedure, conditions precedent, mala fides; satisfaction determinative if exists; cites prior upholding of statute.

holdings.text: Courts may review compliance with procedural safeguards, existence of conditions precedent, mala fides, or collateral purpose, but no basis shown here.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Limited judicial review scope for preventive detention; petitioner adduced no evidence controverting affidavit facts.

holdings.text: Confirmation of detention order by Administrator under Rule 30-A(6)(b) valid after considering all circumstances.

anchor.surface_text: In order to avoid any delay in the disposal of the petition, counsel for the Delhi Administration, showed to me the order of confirmation made by the Administrator and the original order was banded up. The order prima facie suffered from no defect.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Original order produced in court; prima facie no defect; petitioner did not press after inspection; affidavit confirms compliance.

holdings.text: Review under Rule 30-A(8) is executive determination, not quasi-judicial; no duty to act judicially or afford opportunity of hearing to detenu.

anchor.surface_text: Relying upon the use of the expression the Administrator who shall decide upon such review whether the order should be continued or cancelled, it was urged that even if a proceeding directing detention of a person in exercise of powers under Rule 30 1 and a proceeding for confirmation of the order may be purely administrative, a proceeding for review of the order under Rule 30-A 8 is quasi-judicial in character and the Administrator must afford to the detenu an opportunity to make his representation on the action proposed to be taken in regard to him on review. ... In my view there is nosubstance in either of the contentions.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows scheme of DI Rules as emergency executive power; distinguishes Ridge v Baldwin; follows Khushaldas Advani, Nakkuda Ali; no statutory implication of judicial duty.

holdings.text: No principles of natural justice or audi alteram partem apply to review under Rule 30-A(8).
holdings.reasoning_summary: Duty to act judicially not inferred from affecting rights or word 'decide'; depends on statute scheme; not prescribed or implicit.

holdings.text: Administrator's review order dated February 24, 1965 validly reviews the detention order, not merely the confirmation.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Confirmation integral to detention order's continuance; review of confirmed detention order; substance continues detention.

holdings.text: Use of word 'decide' in Rule 30-A(8) does not import judicial approach or duty to act judicially.
holdings.reasoning_summary: 'Decide' neutral; test is manner of arriving at decision; cites Fazl Ali J. in Advani case.
